review_title: My advice would be to look elsewhere
pros:
Benefits were good
Some good colleagues and students
Location
cons:
Believe the other negative reviews. The school used to be a young, high quality, up and coming school that focused on the academic experience of the students. It has degraded to an almost unrecognizable con game of high tuition, low academic standards, toxic culture and limited support. 

Incompetent, unethical cronies are promoted. High achieving dedicated employees are repressed. Other than their tuition checks, students are "irrelevant" to the administration.

Florida Tech has been in a state of financial stress for over a decade but it really started sinking after the current president was appointed. The university has dropped from ~150 in National Universities to unranked by US News in less than three years.

review_title: Proudly Narcissistic Micromanaging Administration - Women watch your back

cons:
If it's not a pet project of Admin's favorite engineering effort, they don't care
Leadership is proudly self-described as Micro-Managers
Where did all the excellent women go from the top ranks in Administration??

review_title: Good, but can be so much better.
pros:
If you work full time you have access to a variety of benefits: health insurance, tuition remission, AT&T discounts, etc.
People here are friendly for the most part.
The department I work for is pretty awesome, however we are getting bigger so office space is kinda cramped. Promotions can happen you have to work for it, otherwise you can collect your minimal 11 cent raise in October every year.
cons:
It's really hard to move up within the organization and I would agree there is a bit of nepotism within the university.
Additionally there are people that you will encounter here that lack drive and proactive-ness.
Once they punch out they don't care much about making the university a better place (that's not to say they should make it their life) but they just don't seem to care about making Florida Tech a the great school it could potentially be. They're pretty much just sitting around waiting to retire.
Also the pay kinda stinks, but it stinks in general for the area. I have a master's from a good state school and I relocated here when I married and started out at $14.00 an hour. Stinky. But I'm not starving so really I guess that's a first world problem.

pros: The place is good with a friendly supervisor and students
cons: Not any I can share

review_title: Excellent choice; not my top choice
pros:
~Career services are a high point.
~My transition to this school was smooth in part because it seemed like the staff truly care and respect us for people we are.
~I have been able to get to know my professors because classes are small.
~ (As a freshman) The workload has been easier than high school.
~They offered an excellent scholarship. I wouldn't have gone otherwise.
~Culturally diverse
~Safe and sheltered campus community overall. From what I have seen and heard, rates of crime are low.
cons:
It doesn't seem right to knock it down a star because its performance in nearly every category is strong and professional by objective standards. For most students, the positives seem to outweigh the negatives. 

The reason I feel tempted to give it four stars is subjective. It hasn't really stood out to me in any aspect beyond student demographics; I suppose I had unrealistic or naive expectations of what college should be. I don't plan on transferring because the major is unique (Bachelor's of Science in Sustainability Studies), but there were excellent- and affordable- schools with cultures I find more appealing. I was disappointed because I was hoping for 1) a less American-centric school (this is one of the most geographically diverse schools in the country, if not the world) and 2) a challenging curriculum. It sounds like the difficulty level is also dependent on which major you choose. This is still early, so I may revise my review in time.

Staff seem underpaid, overworked, and underappreciated. This has flared due to lay offs from COVID-19.

pros: Professors willing to help always
cons: Hard to get hours sometimes

cons: The pay is very mediocre

review_title: Pays peanuts compared to same jobs in other industries.
pros: Nothing, unless you are easily fooled with office snacks.
cons: They earn in millions and pay in pennies. Way lower than average pay for the same positions elsewhere.

pros: Flexible, nice faculty members, sufficient instruction

pros: The company has a great tuition remission and benefits package and there are/were some very talented employees. Some divisions are very hospitable to work in.
cons: This organization has some serious ethics issues. Pay was lower than average for the level of skill, expertise, responsibility and experience. The upper management is disconnected and aloof, and does not value the people who work in the organization. HR is dysfunctional and has no power or will to support the staff. Professional development is lacking with the exception of tuition remission benefits. Raises and promotions are based on cronyism and favoritism, with incompetent and inexperienced staff frequently promoted to high positions based on social connections. There are no formal metrics, and performance evaluations were subjective and not standardized. High performers are not recognized or valued, and I observed several terminations of people who were hard working and brilliant at what they did on the basis of poor management judgments that were rooted in personal relationships.

pros: Chance to make money while studying
cons: Well, they might overwork you.

pros: really bad place to work
cons: don't come here it is bad

pros: Immediate 100% tuition remission for self, 90% for spouse and children. 100% Cost waivers for certifications like Lean, Lean Six Sigma.  Staff gets University holidays off without having to use vacation.  Health Benefits are good but covered by employee.  Employees get $150 a month on a iCUBA card to use toward any medical expenses.
cons: The university goes through frequent hiring freezes and layoffs (though they're working on that).  For the past 2 years there were no performance appraisals and no raises (though they just very recently gave everyone a 3% raise and a bonus after that long dry spell).  The university is run by good-ol'-boys (old white men).  I think the president is a misogynist, based on his speeches to the faculty/staff.

pros:
Students and co-workers are good for the most part.  
I get to work closely with all types of students so I feel good that the work has meaning and is helping others.
Benefits are good.
cons: This place is a rudderless ship.   National and international rankings continue to plummet.  The executive administration is a miserable echo chamber that's completely disconnected from reality.  Infighting and political backstabbing seems to be the norm with constant executive org chart changes and random promotions that make no sense.  I looked up "signs of a sick corporate culture" and every item on all of the lists that popped up exactly match aspects of the leadership at Florida Tech.  Staff pay is very low.

job_title: Grocery Clerk, Grill Cook, Dining Hall Assistant in Melbourne, FL
pros: You will learn a lot.
cons: I was offered employment with the promise of it turning in to a full time position and tuition assistance if I wanted to take classes there. The position was only a 9 month temporary position and I was not told this in the interview. I ended up having to find out from another manager. I also got paid $1.00 less than another employee with the same title as me, except I worked immensely harder and was even told this by my own boss. She even told me they were hoping she would quit, they didn't want to fire her because they didn't want to have to pay her unemployment. If you were dissatisfied with something you had to keep it to yourself. The management team is not friendly nor open to hearing suggestions or complaints.

review_title: Avoid the Security Department as the plague.
pros:
They are no pros working in Security but the pay.
Use of accrued sick time is frowned upon and used against you in yearly evaluations.
Tuition remission for the Officer, 1 credit per semester online, 2 credits per semester if you attend on campus.
cons:
1.No real room for growth.
2.No appreciation for the officers.
3.Be prepared to be liable and written up for mistakes of the other Departments.
4.Mandatory Overtime if your the new guy, and you will be the new guy for a while.
5.If your not part of the good ole boy system you will never succeed.
6.Most important of all MANAGEMENT has been there so long with under staffing that they arent willing to think outside the box.
7.Lots of micromanaging, nitpicking, management does not have anything better else to do.
8. You have been warned avoid if you have previous law enforcement experience you will not be appreciated for your skills or knowledge.
9.Avoid,avoid the Security Department there have been other grievances against the Security Departments Management and nothing has happened so you have been advised.

review_title: If you can put with a lot then this is the job for you!
job_title: Panther Dining Hall Cook in Melbourne, FL
pros: They are very flexible with scheduling, the work is easy and repetitive so you are sure to have it down packed in no time, the pay is pretty decent. Free food while you are on the clock, benefites are great. Free tuition! You get to meet a lot of diverse people!
cons: A LOT of favoritism! The "favorites" are usually subpar workers but brown-nosers of course. Complete double standards. Unprofessional employees that bring way too much drama to work. Usually always understaffed or you're stuck with crappy workers so you have to do 2x the work. Very cliquey at times. He said she said drama as well. Almost everyone does drugs.

review_title: A cruise ship of a career awaits you...
pros: A great working community, with all the rich diversity a university campus can offer. Fantastic benefits, including tuition remission for employees and their families. Everything goes by the academic calendar, in general there are few real "emergencies". It's a wonderful place to work at if you value your family and home life.
cons: Pay is generally below other academic institutions, and as far as IT goes, well below what an IT professional would make in business. Still, the benefits may offset that for you; I know they did for me. University politics can be brutal as well.

pros: I have had some opportunities for growth within the organization, which has been great for my professional career.  I've also been able to earn my degree, which I probably would not have been able to get if I weren't working here.  It's really a wonderful company to work for!
cons: It has its share of internal office politics, just like any business.  Also, some people within the organization aren't receptive to change, which can hinder growth.  And, in general, the salary for staff is highly undervalued compared to faculty.

review_title: There are better colleges to work for
pros: I have my own office with a window, there are a variety of places to eat lunch within a 10 minute drive of campus, most of the coworkers in my department are great, my boss is pretty hands-off and lets me do what I need to do without interfering, decent health insurance.
cons: When president McCay took office, he took away our raises (2 years now), initiated layoffs and demotions, started hiring freezes, and told us FIT wouldn't match our retirement investments anymore. Everyone who made a certain amount of money was switched from salary to hourly, even though the minimum wage law never went into effect in FL. Still, they kept us hourly but let the supervisors go back to salary. Faculty is treated like golden children here - they still get their raises. You are forced to pay for parking as en employee and it is  very difficult to find during the Fall and Spring semesters. I took a large pay cut to come here from a public university. The wage here is unacceptable. President McCay can be quite rude and offensive at times. He made a fool of himself at a holiday party by saying demeaning things to the staff - clearly, he had a few drinks. He has also said some offensive things to myself regarding my age.

review_title: Too many "human touches," not enough "high tech."
pros:
On its face, working for Florida Institute of Technology is a great resume-builder. The private university's educational reputation certainly precedes it, and there is something to say for the work experience you can obtain while employed here.

For full-time employees, the benefits package is considerable. After the initial three-month probationary period, it includes: 

Bi-weekly accruing vacation and sick time,
Paid Holidays,
Paid two-week Winter Break vacation,
403c (non-profit 401k equivalent),
Insurance (life, health, dental, eye),
Tuition remission (up to 6 credit hours/semester),
and more.
cons:
Florida Institute of Technology is currently experiencing budgetary issues, the result of overspending. This means that layoffs have been, and continue to be, prevalent across multiple departments and multiple levels.

Turnover is very high as a result, and moral is noticeably suffering. 

We have not received a cost of living adjustment, let alone a raise in pay, in the time that I have been here (which was promised, but later rescinded).

The university took away the company match for the 403c for an undisclosed amount of time (it was promised that was not going to happen, either) in order to save on budget.

Based on my experience, there is generally little support from management when it comes to backing up their employees when the going gets tough. The buck tends to be quickly passed along the the lower-levels.

Make no mistake; the executives and faculty take precedent over the staff, and perhaps even the students here. Upper management will time and time again bend over backwards and submit to the will of faculty members, even in the face of long-standing university policies.

There is poor communication between departments, if any occurs at all.

From what I can tell,

pros:
-Paid holiday winter break. 
-Good tuition remission policies that become hard to use at the graduate level due to inflated tuition costs. 
-ICuba card
-The department staff I worked with were, generally, amazing (but I have heard horror stories of other departments)
cons:
-Salaries are dismal for the education levels they want their staff to maintain.
-You must pay to park as an employee (at a cost higher than students). 
-You will work spring break.
-No advancement and very hard to transition departments. If you are a good employee your supervisor will hold on to you, no matter your wants or needs.
-Poor management, across the board. They will do what is easy, long before what is right.
-"Top 10" management in the school rake in millions while staff try to get by on bare bone salaries.
-New president but seemingly the old is still being paid as a member of the "faculty".
-No raises for the last couple years, for staff, also the 401k match has stopped.
-Currently seeing a lot of turn over in my old department and through the school.
-Past president was raking in a higher salary than the presidents at such universities as Harvard, Stanford and Cornell. Let that sink in. I will be interested to see where McKay ends up on the Forbes list.

review_title: If you are happy with the lowest of the low pay, Florida Tech wants you!
pros:
1. Generous paid time off by book, but you can't take those when you need.

2.  You can always hear the worthless gratitude if that's what you can live on instead of monetary compensation
cons:
1. One of the lowest pay in the nation while making tons in profit to fill the pockets of the executives
2. Understaffed all year long
3. Be ready to work others' job without notice
4. When someone leaves, his/her job comes to your plate without hiring a replacement staff immediately
5. If you don't look for other jobs immediately after getting hired, you'll feel only worthy of this place this after spending here a short time.

review_title: It was a good place to work part-time as a current, international student.
pros: Connections. If you are interested in making connections in the professional world, the faculty at FIT is very well connected with industry leaders.
cons: They pay minimum wage and don't allow you to work more than 20 hours per week. It is difficult to make money while going to school there.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Melbourne, FL
pros:
1) Flexible work study hours.
2) Plenty on the job learning.
3) Whatever work or skills you do or learn generally transfer over to classes easily.
cons:
1) It's difficult to gain entry into a research based work study as an undergrad. It's much easier to present a case if you have previous research experience, programming experience, or Linux/Network experience.
2) Professors usually aren't around when you need them.
3) The research transfers well for career opportunities, if you're looking to get an MS and PhD. If not, it's almost useless without some excellent connections.

pros: I worked as a game operations assistant there as a part time employee in athletics department while doing my graduate studies. It's an amazing place to work in and I learned a lot working in this position.
cons: There are only two cons. You need to work on the games you like or dislike. Secondly pay scale is low comparing to other on campus jobs available.

review_title: Love the job, I have no real complaints.
job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Melbourne, FL
pros:
Working with students is great, they're mostly very competent, particularly those in upper division classes.

There are no real requirements on where and when you work (other than of course teaching the classes themselves), so it makes for a very flexible schedule. (Mileage may vary depending on departments and professors.)
cons: GSAs mostly only teach lab sections in my department. It would be nice for professional development to have greater responsibilities over courses, although I understand the preference for having professors lecture more.

review_title: Good Place to Work and Get a Masters
pros: Friendly People, Get a Masters for Free, Good Benefits, Retirement, Plenty of Vacation Days
cons: Need to Be Salaried, High Turnover because people come for their masters, Pay is a little low, Budget is allocated through unknown means, People are always complaining about not enough money spent on this or that

pros: great facilities, small classes. It is a great experience for an upcoming professor to gain some experience in class management, curriculum development , and institutional rules.
cons: Lots of politics and red tape. The salary is very low for the amount of work, that includes curriculum development, class delivery, office hours and students follow up

pros: Good benefits, friendly office staff
cons:
I don’t even know if I could begin to tell you about the mismanagement of this university and the departments. The reorganization was one of the stupidest things they could possibly have done, especially to Engineering. Most of my colleagues privately agree that the quality of education, and the “dynamic” nature of the changes forced upon by the higher ups is a major negative, but none will vocalize that publicly. 

There’s low morale, blatant favoritism, nepotism, gross mismanagement, and horrible incompetence everywhere you look.

pros: In general, the environment is not stressful, especially if you don't need the money, and only the benefits.
cons: There are a lot of people in high leadership positions who are not interested in changing anything for the better. There is still VERY MUCH a 'good ol boy' culture. If you need to be the breadwinner for your family you should look at other companies in the area.

pros: There is a shared sense of purpose to provide a quality education for our students. Faculty and staff work well together.
cons: There is a lack of direction at the College of Science level. If the College worked together as a cohesive unit this would improve working conditions.

job_title: Adjunct Professor, Oceanography in Melbourne, FL
pros: I am retired, so only want to work on a part time job, which this job is. I have worked full time in other jobs for over forty years.
cons: Contracted each semester with no assurance of ongoing contracts. Pay is very low, and does not reflect value of many years of experience.

review_title: Educationally this was an amazing experience where as the social experience was a bit unusual.
pros: I meet some very unique people during my studies and tool classes that were equally as unique.
cons: It was hard to have a social life while attempting to pass coarses.

review_title: A good educational institution to work for when first starting out.
job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Melbourne, FL
pros: My peers and supervisors were a great team. New ideas from my end were entertained and even executed. I was even allowed highly responsible work just a few months into my position.
cons: Not a very upwardly mobile organization. Does not focus as much as it needs to on the needs of international students even though it has a large international population.

pros:
Great benefits package... especially tuition assistance.
(department depending) very understanding about time off for illness and vacation... particularly during summer months when fewer students are on campus.
cons: Quite a bit of nepotism all over campus. limited recognition for a job well done. faculty basically guaranteed a yearly pay increase while staff are expected to stick around for very minimal raises.

review_title: Incompetence run amok.  No support for faculty or staff.
pros:
Location.  
The students are great.
Some good co-workers.
Campus is nice.
cons:
Promotions are based on affiliation and friendship, not on the objective criteria listed in the handbooks or in accordance with performance evaluations.  Consequently, the people who have risen to management level positions are often incompetent and substantially increase the workload of the employees under them who must constantly cover for them or suffer under random, directionless rule.  Faculty and staff are treated with little to no respect.  Competent managers and workers tend to be suppressed by the incompetent.

 Productivity has suffered, morale is as low as I've seen anywhere in my 30+ year working life, turnover is very high.  Workload has continuously increased while wages have remained stagnant.  There have been no merit increases or cost of living increases in three years.  Lots of "what have you done for me today" and "you scratch my back, I'll scratch yours" going on.  

I started working for Florida Tech with a positive outlook and a lot of enthusiasm for the potential future.  Now it has become obvious that advancement is limited and I must make a move to another organization to finish my career.  Looking across other departments, the situation seems to be common everywhere within the organization.  

To sum it up, someone who is competent, driven, responsible and feels a desire to serve the students and due their job properly will be extremely frustrated at Florida Tech.  Anyone who believes in the rule of law and following written policies will be frustrated at Florida Tech.

review_title: Favoritism, Bad Management, Incompetence and low pay.
pros: Paid Holidays on winter break, 401k match (sometimes), benefits card you can use for medical co-pays.
cons:
Promotions are based on friendship, so basically the many VPs, Directors, etc. are 90% incompetent and substantially increase the workload on their employees who are underpaid and suffer under directionless rule and random tasks.  Managers take credit for employees work, and and staff treated with little respect.  Total incompetence, and disregard for policies that regular staff MUST follow.   Double standards are the norm, and any HR oversight is slim if any.  

Constant turnover of good employees, while whitless managers live in endless meetings and make unreal, and clueless suggestions, while what remaining staff try to keep the place functioning,.

so-called "merit increases are a university-wide joke as evaluations are made by people who often have no idea what the employee actually does.  There is utterly low morale, heavy turnover of mainly good employees, turnover of CFOs due to incompetence, President has an entourage of VP's and assistant VP's and Directors, but hardly NO middle competent managers.  No assistant directors, and little staff.  VERY top heavy in a ridiculous way, especially when always in a budget crisis.

Communication is hideous.  The worst I've seen in my entire work history.  Everything is secretive and every department runs differently.  NO consistency and promotions are made by friendships, brown-nosing, and coat-tail riding.  Hiring is pathetic as some jobs are listed and open to the public, and some people are just promoted when the managers choose.

review_title: Had a great experience, picked up a lot of skills
pros: Great environment, great people. They were very flexible and had great mentoring. I picked up skills very quickly from their training.
cons: Some tasks are not fully automated, but not because of the technology, it was more due to policies that we had to follow. Some work ended up being done repetitively and manually.

review_title: Not a bad place to work unless you have a bad manager.
pros: Good benefits, challenging, excellent vacation time, friendly work environment, beautiful campus with a decent cafeteria, good HR department
cons: Below average salaries, politics, some managers are really bad to the point of being abusive, managers often don't understand the Americans with disabilities act and are known to violate it.

pros: Quality faculty. Great location, close to the beach. Students from all around the world.
cons: Expectations of faculty are that of a tenured R1 university, but the teaching load is higher and the pay is lower.  Tough place to be if you're a woman.

pros: My work directly helps people do well in their classes, and I enjoy the satisfaction of helping others understand difficult concepts.
cons: I'm a student, so I'm not quite privy to how much of the university runs. But in regards to my job, I don't have cons.

job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Melbourne, FL
pros: They pay for my PhD tuition, which would be $17K an year.
cons: Student quality varies broadly. Dealing with dull students is extremely painful. Students seems to have a strong attitude of being entitled to pass the class because they pay the tuition. The school support this kind of behavior.

pros:
Very little micro management
Ideas are supported
Professional development is abundant
Departments are well supported by academic departments
Students are outstanding
cons:
Little pay
Low leadership ability of top leaders
No women nor minorities in any top positions. 
Lack of direction on the goals

pros: Great approachability of manager. Easy to talk to supervisors. Relaxed work environment.
cons: Low pay. Long hours. Boring job. Can get distracted and tired easily.

review_title: Okay place to work, until today
pros: Worker there part time driving the trolley and shuttle buses, today they called 9 of us (there are 12 in the dept) in and laid us off due to budget cuts
cons: No medical, never more than 30 hours per week

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Melbourne, FL
pros: The biomedical engineering department at FIT has a friendly work environment with easy access to professors or faculty to help you if you ever need a hand with something.
cons: Lack of solid funding as well as very few on campus resources for scientific testing made performing some types of research difficult.

pros: Florida Institute of Technology keeps me in school, and gives me good education. Proud to be a panther.
cons: Unfortunately, we have low wages, not much time off. We also, have bad reviews because our students have a hard time paying their loans back.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Melbourne, FL
pros: Depending on the professor you're working for and how much funding he/she has, you can get your tuition fully covered.
cons: Low pay, a lot of work

pros: Co-workers were fun to be around for the most part. My supervisor was excellent and very fair. Compensation included housing and meal-plan for the summer.
cons: My boss's boss often asked us to do jobs that should not have been given to us. Variable hours meant that pay wasn't constant.

review_title: Best place to work, as a student, is at the library.
pros: Easy, and i could do coursework while working
cons: The pay wasn't the best. I was making 9.50 after working there for 4 years!

review_title: Great place to work if you are able to work year round.
pros:
Fun, friendly staff and management.
Fun environment to work.
Excellent benefits.
cons:
Difficult to be employed year 'round: most staff is only 9 months.
Parking can be hard to find at times.
Payscale is low.

review_title: Satisfied with Florida Tech experience overall.
pros:
Benefits are the best, especially tuition remission
Great friendly coworkers
Beautiful campus
Consistent cost-of-living increases
Profession development budget for some
cons:
There is a 15% cap on salary increase with promotions
Constant change (some cannot adapt to)
Layoffs last year left most on edge about job security

pros: Strong face-to-face teaching, a good place for undergraduate students to learn and mature. I enjoyed playing my role in that.
cons: The usual politics, budget pressures, and tensions arising from different standards of online vs face-to-face education.

pros: The school will very actively help you search for on campus jobs or aid you in searching for internships/co-ops.
cons: Many on-campus jobs are not very relevant to a STEM career, so you'll have to seek a little more for something resume worthy

pros: Great family to work with. Tuition benefit for employee and his/her dependents is fantastic.
cons: Very low pay rate for a full time job with a bachelor's degree.

pros: I enjoyed working with people who had a lot of experience  in optical fiber communications. learning to build optical networks and with optical components

pros: Great mentor/boss, fair salary for the position.  Good admin and support.
cons: I wish there wasn't a cap on the amount of hours the department could fund graduate students for.  There is a 20 hour per week cap.

pros: There is nothing special in this place.
